greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the exponent of the least power of 2 that when multiplied by n, makes the product nondeficient, or -1 if n itself is a power of 2.
comment: Number of iterations of x -> 2x needed before the result is nondeficient (sigma(x) >= 2x), when starting from x=n, or -1 if a nondeficient number would never be reached (when n is a power of 2).
If neither x and y are powers of 2, and gcd(x,y) = 1, then a(x*y) <= min(a(x),a(y)). Compare to a similar comment in A336835.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
formula: For odd primes p, a(p) = A000523(p).
program: (PARI) A336915(n) = if(!bitand(n,n-1), -1, for(i=0,oo,my(n2 = n+n); if(sigma(n) >= n2, return(i)); n = n2));
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Aug 08 2020
